Article.Abstract: The structure of a bacterial superantigen, Staphylococcus aureus enterotoxin B, bound to a human class II histocompatibility complex molecule (HLA-DR1) has been determined by X-ray crystallography. The superantigen binds as an intact protein outside the conventional peptide antigen-binding site of the class II major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecule. No large conformational changes occur upon complex formation in either the DR1 or the enterotoxin B molecules. The structure of the complex helps explain how different class II molecules and superantigens associate and suggests a model for ternary complex formation with the T-cell antigen receptor (TCR), in which unconventional TCR-MHC contacts are possible.
Article.ArticleTitle: Three-dimensional structure of a human class II histocompatibility molecule complexed with superantigen.
Article.Affiliations: Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02138.

Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Amino Acid Sequence; Animals; Crystallography, X-Ray; Enterotoxins(chemistry; immunology); HLA-DR1 Antigen(chemistry); Humans; Macromolecular Substances; Mice; Models, Molecular; Molecular Sequence Data; Receptors, Antigen, T-Cell(metabolism); Staphylococcus aureus(immunology); Superantigens(chemistry; immunology)

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The crystal structure contains the MHC/epitope complex bound to the superantigen (SAG) staphylococcal enterotoxin type B (SEB). SAG PDB chain is D, H. There are two MHC/epitope-SAG complexes in the asymmetric unit that form a dimer. Chains in each molecule are: complex I: ABCD , complex II: EFGH. The order of the chains in each complex is: α-chain, β-chain, epitope chain, SAG chain. Interpretable electron density, for the epitope, was found for the main-chain of a 13 residue peptide. Epitope side-chain density was also good in this region. The peptide conformation is based on fitting a polyalanine chain into the observed electron density corresponding to a mixture of self-peptides bound to the HLA-DR1 molecule. Electron density was disordered for the MHC residues 105 - 111 and SAG residues 2 - 9, 127 -153, and 171 -175. The SAG region with the best ordered electron density was the N-terminal domain of the molecule.
